nub.processing

Class Scene

  • java.lang.Object
    • nub.core.Graph
      • nub.processing.Scene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PConstants

    public class Scene
extends Graph
implements PConstants
    A 2D or 3D interactive, on-screen or off-screen, Processing mouse-driven Graph.

    Usage

    Typical usage comprises two steps: scene instantiation and setting some nodes.

    Scene instantiation

    Instantiate your on-screen scene at the PApplet.setup(): 
     
 Scene scene;
 void setup() {
   scene = new Scene(this);
 }
    The scene context() corresponds to the PApplet main canvas.

    Off-screen scenes should be instantiated upon a PGraphics object: 

     
 Scene scene;
 PGraphics canvas;
 void setup() {
   canvas = createGraphics(500, 500, P3D);
   scene = new Scene(this, canvas);
   // or use the equivalent (to the previous two lines) but simpler version:
   // scene = new Scene(this, P3D, 500, 500);
 }
    In this case, the scene context() corresponds to the canvas.

    Drawing functionality

    There are several static drawing functions that complements those already provided by Processing, such as: drawCylinder(PGraphics, int, float, float), drawHollowCylinder(PGraphics, int, float, float, Vector, Vector), drawCone(PGraphics, int, float, float, float, float), drawCone(PGraphics, int, float, float, float, float, float) and drawTorusSolenoid(PGraphics, int, int, float, float).

    Drawing functions that take a PGraphics parameter (including the above static ones), such as beginHUD(PGraphics), endHUD(PGraphics), drawAxes(PGraphics, float), drawCross(PGraphics, float, float, float) and drawGrid(PGraphics) among others, can be used to set a Node.setShape(Object) (see also Node.graphics(PGraphics)).

    Another scene's eye (different than the graph Graph.eye()) can be drawn with drawFrustum(Graph). Typical usage include interactive minimaps and visibility culling visualization and debugging.

    An Interpolator path may be drawn with code like this: 

     
 void draw() {
   scene.render();
   scene.drawPath(interpolator, 5);
 }
    while Graph.render() will draw the animated node(s), drawPath(Interpolator, int) will draw the interpolated path too.

    Human Interface Devices

    The default Human Interface Device is the Processing mouse, see updateMouseTag(), mouseTag(), mouseSpin(), mouseTranslate() Graph.scale(float), etc. To set up another device refer to the Graph documentation.
    See Also:
    Graph, Node, Interpolator

      • Scene

        public Scene(PApplet pApplet,
             PGraphics pGraphics,
             int x,
             int y)
        Main constructor defining a left-handed Processing compatible scene. Calls Graph.setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler) using a customized MatrixHandler depending on the context() type (see GLMatrixHandler).

        An off-screen Processing scene is defined if pGraphics != pApplet.g. In this case the x and y parameters define the position of the upper-left corner where the off-screen scene is expected to be displayed, see display(). If pGraphics == pApplet.g) (which defines an on-screen scene, see also Graph.isOffscreen()), the values of x and y are meaningless (both are set to 0 to be taken as dummy values). Render into an off-screen graph requires the drawing code to be enclose by beginDraw() and endDraw(). To display an off-screen scene call display().

        See Also:
        Graph.Graph(Object, nub.core.Graph.Type, int, int), Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphics), Scene(PApplet, String, int, int), Scene(PApplet, String, int, int, int, int), Scene(PApplet, String)

      • setCenterFromPixel

        public boolean setCenterFromPixel(int pixelX,
                                  int pixelY)
        The Graph.center() is set to the point located under pixel on screen.

        2D windows always returns true.

        3D Cameras returns true if a point was found under pixel and false if none was found (in this case no Graph.center() is set).

      • pixelDepth

        public float pixelDepth(int pixelX,
                        int pixelY)
        Returns the depth (z-value) of the object under the pixel. Used by pointUnderPixel(int, int).

        The z-value ranges in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D note that this value is not a linear interpolation between Graph.zNear() and Graph.zFar(): z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z') where z' is the distance from the point you project to the eye, along the Graph.viewDirection().

        See Also:
        pointUnderPixel(int, int)

      • pointUnderPixel

        public Vector pointUnderPixel(int pixelX,
                              int pixelY)
        Returns the world coordinates of the 3D point located at pixel (x,y) on screen. May be null if no object is under pixel.

      • pre

        public void pre()
        Paint method which is called just before your PApplet.draw() method. Simply handles resize events. This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it. Only meaningful if the graph is on-screen (it the graph Graph.isOffscreen() it even doesn't get registered at the PApplet.

        If context() is resized then (re)sets the graph Graph.width() and Graph.height(), and calls Graph.setWidth(int) and Graph.setHeight(int).

        See Also:
        draw(), Graph.render(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), Graph.isOffscreen()

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Paint method which is called just after your PApplet.draw() method. Simply render the back buffer (useful for picking). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it. Only meaningful if the graph is on-screen (it the graph Graph.isOffscreen() it even doesn't get registered at the PApplet.

        If Graph.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        See Also:
        pre(), Graph.render(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), Graph.isOffscreen()

      • beginDraw

        public void beginDraw()
        Only if the scene Graph.isOffscreen(). Calls context().beginDraw() (hence there's no need to explicitly call it).

        If context() is resized then (re)sets the graph Graph.width() and Graph.height(), and calls Graph.setWidth(int) and Graph.setHeight(int).

        See Also:
        draw(), Graph.render(), pre(), endDraw(), Graph.isOffscreen(), context()

      • endDraw

        public void endDraw()
        Only if the scene Graph.isOffscreen(). Calls:
        1. context().endDraw() and hence there's no need to explicitly call it
        2. _updateBackBuffer(): Render the back buffer (useful for picking)
        See Also:
        draw(), Graph.render(), beginDraw(), pre(), Graph.isOffscreen(), context()

      • display

      • beginHUD

        public void beginHUD(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Begins Heads Up Display (HUD) on the pGraphics so that drawing can be done using 2D screen coordinates. Don't forget to call endHUD(PGraphics) after screen drawing ends.

        All screen drawing should be enclosed between beginHUD(PGraphics) and endHUD(PGraphics). Then you can just begin drawing your screen nodes. Attention: If you want your screen drawing to appear on top of your 3d graph then draw first all your 3d before doing any call to a beginHUD(PGraphics) and endHUD(PGraphics) pair.

        See Also:
        endHUD(PGraphics), beginHUD()

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(Interpolator interpolator,
                     int mask,
                     int steps)
        Convenience function that simply calls drawPath(interpolator, mask, count, radius()).
        See Also:
        drawPath(Interpolator, int, int, float)

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(Interpolator interpolator,
                     int mask,
                     int steps,
                     float scale)
        Draws the Interpolator path.

        mask controls what is drawn: If ( (mask & 1) != 0 ), the position path is drawn. If ( (mask & 2) != 0 ), an eye representation is regularly drawn and if ( (mask & 4) != 0 ), oriented axes are regularly drawn. Examples:

        drawPath(1); // Simply draws the interpolation path
        drawPath(3); // Draws path and eyes
        drawPath(5); // Draws path and axes

        In the case where the eye or axes are drawn, steps controls the number of objects (axes or eyes) drawn between two successive keyframes. When steps = 1, only the keyframes are drawn, when steps = 2 it also draws the intermediate orientation, etc. The maximum value is 30, so that an object is drawn for each keyframe. Default value is 6.

        scale controls the scaling of the eye and axes drawing. A value of Graph.radius() should give good results.

      • drawArrow

        public void drawArrow(float length)
        Simply calls drawArrow(length, 0.05f * length)
        See Also:

        Parameters:
        detail -
        radius - radius of the hollow cylinder
        height - height of the hollow cylinder
        normal1 - normal of the plane that intersects the cylinder at z=0
        normal2 - normal of the plane that intersects the cylinder at z=height
        See Also:
        drawCylinder(float, float)

      • drawFrustum

        public void drawFrustum(Graph graph)
        Applies the graph.eye() transformation (see Graph.applyTransformation(Node)) and then calls drawFrustum(PGraphics, Graph) on the scene context().
        See Also:
        drawFrustum(PGraphics, Graph), #drawFrustum(PGraphics, PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float), #drawFrustum(PGraphics, PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float, boolean)

      • drawFrustum

        public void drawFrustum(PGraphics pGraphics,
                        Graph graph)
        Draws a representation of the viewing frustum onto pGraphics according to graph.eye() and graph.type().

        Note that if pGraphics == graph.context() this method has not effect at all.

        See Also:
        drawFrustum(Graph), #drawFrustum(PGraphics, PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float), #drawFrustum(PGraphics, PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float, boolean)

      • drawFrustum

        public static void drawFrustum(PGraphics pGraphics,
                               PGraphics eyeBuffer,
                               Graph.Type type,
                               Node eye,
                               float zNear,
                               float zFar)
        Same as drawFrustum(pGraphics, eyeBuffer, type, eye, zNear, zFar, true).
        See Also:
        drawFrustum(Graph), drawFrustum(PGraphics, Graph), #drawFrustum(PGraphics, PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float, boolean)

      • drawFrustum

        public static void drawFrustum(PGraphics pGraphics,
                               PGraphics eyeBuffer,
                               Graph.Type type,
                               Node eye,
                               float zNear,
                               float zFar,
                               boolean leftHanded)
        Draws a representation of the eyeBuffer frustum onto pGraphics according to frustum parameters: type, eye Node.magnitude(), zNear and zFar, while taking into account whether or not the scene is leftHanded.

        Use it in conjunction with #render(PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float, boolean) as when rendering a shadow map.

        See Also:
        drawFrustum(Graph), drawFrustum(PGraphics, Graph), #drawFrustum(PGraphics, PGraphics, Type, Node, float, float)

      • drawProjectors

        public void drawProjectors(PGraphics pGraphics,
                           Graph graph,
                           java.util.List<Vector> points)
        Draws the projection of each point in points in the near plane onto pGraphics.

        This method should be used in conjunction with drawFrustum(PGraphics, Graph).

        Note that if graph == this this method has not effect at all.

        See Also:
        drawProjector(PGraphics, Graph, Vector)

      • drawCross

        public void drawCross(Node node)
        drawCross(float, float, float) centered at the projected node origin. If node is a Node instance the length of the cross is the node Node.pickingThreshold(), otherwise it's Graph.radius() / 5. If node a Node instance and it is Graph.hasTag(Node) it also applies a stroke highlight.
        See Also:
        drawSquaredBullsEye(Node, float)

      • drawCross

                      float length)

        See Also:
        drawCross(float, float, float)

      • drawBullsEye

        public void drawBullsEye(Node node)
        Draws a bullseye around the node Node.position() projection.

        The shape of the bullseye may be squared or circled depending on the node Node.pickingThreshold() sign.

        See Also:
        Node.pickingThreshold(), Node.position(), drawSquaredBullsEye(Node), drawCircledBullsEye(Node)

      • drawSquaredBullsEye

        public void drawSquaredBullsEye(Node node)
        drawSquaredBullsEye(float, float, float) centered at the projected node origin. The length of the target is the node Node.pickingThreshold(). If node Graph.hasTag(Node) it also applies a stroke highlight.
        See Also:
        drawSquaredBullsEye(Node, float), drawCircledBullsEye(Node), drawBullsEye(Node)

                                     int faces,

                                     float insideRadius,
                                     float outsideRadius)
        Draws a torus solenoid onto pGraphics.

        Code contributed by Jacques Maire (http://www.alcys.com/) See also: http://www.mathcurve.com/courbes3d/solenoidtoric/solenoidtoric.shtml http://crazybiocomputing.blogspot.fr/2011/12/3d-curves-toric-solenoids.html

        Parameters:

        detail -
        insideRadius -
        outsideRadius -

                     java.util.List<Vector> vertices,
                     float scale)

        It is desirable that each point in vertices lie inside the unit Sphere

        scale -
